title: Orchard planted by non-member
vignette: An orchard was planted by a non-member but sold to a community member before the first fruits matured. Does it qualify for first fruits offering?

options.text: Qualifies; the current community member owner bears the obligation.
Disqualifies; original planting by a non-member taints the produce.

title: Orchard sold to non-member then reacquired
vignette: An orchard planted by a community member was sold to a non-member, then later repurchased by a community member before harvest. Does it qualify for first fruits offering?

options.text: Qualifies; final community member ownership restores its status.
Disqualifies; interim non-member ownership invalidates it.

title: Sharecropper’s First Fruits Offering
vignette: A sharecropper cultivates homeland owned by another community member. Who must bring the first fruits?

options.text: Sharecropper; he did the work and harvested the fruit.

title: Co-owned orchard by community member and non-member
vignette: An orchard is jointly owned by a community member and a non-member. Do its fruits qualify for first fruits offering?

options.text: Qualifies; the community member owner’s share suffices.
Disqualifies; any non-member stake disqualifies the produce.

title: Returnee’s recitation
vignette: An community member who lived abroad then returned brings first fruits offering. Should he recite the standard “passed down through generations” formula or a modified version?

options.text: Standard formula; join the collective heritage.
Modified version; clarify his personal return.

title: New Community Member’s confession
vignette: A new community member stands among first fruits offering presenters. Must he recite a unique confession acknowledging his personal exchange or the standard communal declaration?

options.text: Unique confession; reflect his individual journey.
Standard declaration; emphasize unity over individuality.

title: Contaminated presenter carrying basket
vignette: A man who is ritually contaminated from contact with a dead body causing contamination brings his first fruits offering basket to the central assembly place hill. May he leave the basket there and depart without entering?

options.text: Yes; the basket may be placed even if he cannot ascend.
No; contamination invalidates the offering entirely.

title: Deaf-mute gesture blessings
vignette: A presenter is deaf-mute and cannot recite the blessing verbally. Should he use gestures to fulfill the obligation?

options.text: Yes; gestures suffice to convey the required intent.
No; verbal recitation is mandated by law.

title: Double designation of first fruits
vignette: A farmer ties a reed band around a fruit to mark it as first fruits. Must he also repeat that designation after picking it?

options.text: Yes; both field-marking and post-harvest declaration are required.
No; the initial in-field marking suffices.
